Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: Travel for Students and Postdocs to attend the 14th Congress of the International Society for Developmental and Comparative Immunology in Santa Fe, NM, June 17-21, 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the attendance of students and postdoctoral fellows at the 14th Congress of the International Society for Developmental and Comparative Immunology in Santa Fe, NM on June 17 - 21, 2018. The Congress enhances research in immunology through presentations of current research and discussions of immune function in a wide variety of organisms. Comparative and evolutionary studies of the immune responses in non-mammalian species have led to groundbreaking work, such as the identification of the function of receptors in pathogen recognition and host defense. These immune strategies have been major discoveries that have advanced the wider field of immunology. The Congress will promote discussion between early career scientists and students with leaders in the field of comparative immunology, providing valuable opportunities for young scientists to interact with them and establish professional networks essential to their careers. Understanding how different animals respond to infections can enhance knowledge of human responses to infections and potentially lead to new therapies.

The 14th Congress of the International Society for Developmental and Comparative Immunology brings together scientists who study the immune systems of different species. Studies of comparative immunology have led to groundbreaking discoveries such as Toll-like receptors and RNAi as a host defense mechanism. The conference is designed to maximize formal and informal interaction between scientists at all levels. Supported participants will submit a summary of a session of their choosing. These reports will be compiled into a meeting report that will be published and disseminated through publication in the ISDCI journal, Developmental and Comparative Immunology. Organizers have a commitment to gender balance and encourage attendance by underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this award nineteen trainees were supported to travel from US research labs to the 14th Congress of the International Society for Developmental and Comparative Immunology Santa Fe, New Mexico, June 17th-21st, 2018. Students represented eleven states and the District of Columbia, eleven females and seven males, and multiple ethnicities. All of these students presented their research at this triennial international, yet student friendly, meeting. Additionally, travel support recipients were tasked with summarizing sections of the conference and all are authors on a travel report that was published earlier this year (Abernathy et al. Developmental and Comparative Immunology 96:83-92, 2019). One masters student was supported, three postdoctoral fellows and the rest were PhD students.

Importantly, due to the relatively inexpensive destination of Santa Fe We were able to support these students on much less than was budgeted and returned money to the NSF. Due to the leveraging of other funds some tranees Bursaries were as low as $138 and the most expensive was $753. The overall experence reported by the awardees was positive and will help retain these your people in science.  I hope to compete for similar support to get students to the next Congress in 2021 in Dailan China. This upcoming request will undoubtedly be for more funds.
